raw_text:
Ethiopia's crop production up 24%
 
 Ethiopia produced 14.27 million tonnes of crops in 2004, 24% higher than in 2003 and 21% more than the average of the past five years, a report says.
 
 In 2003, crop production totalled 11.49 million tonnes, the joint report from the Food and Agriculture Organisation and the World Food Programme said. Good rains, increased use of fertilizers and improved seeds contributed to the rise in production. Nevertheless, 2.2 million Ethiopians will still need emergency assistance.
 
 The report calculated emergency food requirements for 2005 to be 387,500 tonnes. On top of that, 89,000 tonnes of fortified blended food and vegetable oil for "targeted supplementary food distributions for a survival programme for children under five and pregnant and lactating women" will be needed.
 
 In eastern and southern Ethiopia, a prolonged drought has killed crops and drained wells. Last year, a total of 965,000 tonnes of food assistance was needed to help seven million Ethiopians. The Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) recommend that the food assistance is bought locally. "Local purchase of cereals for food assistance programmes is recommended as far as possible, so as to assist domestic markets and farmers," said Henri Josserand, chief of FAO's Global Information and Early Warning System. Agriculture is the main economic activity in Ethiopia, representing 45% of gross domestic product. About 80% of Ethiopians depend directly or indirectly on agriculture.
llama3.2:1b: Ethiopia's crop production increased by 24% to 14.27 million tonnes in 2004 compared to 2003 and up by 21% from the previous five years, according to a report.
However, 2.2 million Ethiopians will still need emergency assistance due to droughts affecting crops and wells.
The Food and Agriculture Organisation recommends local purchase of cereals for food assistance programs to assist domestic markets and farmers.
llama3.2:3b: Ethiopia produced 14.27 million tonnes of crops in 2004, a 24% increase from 2003.
The rise was due to good rains, fertilizer use and improved seeds.
However, 2.2 million Ethiopians needed emergency assistance, with total requirements for 2005 at 387,500 tonnes.
Local purchase of food assistance is recommended by the FAO to support domestic markets and farmers.

Despite the increase, 2.2 million Ethiopians require emergency food assistance.
The report estimates a need for 387,500 tonnes of food aid in 2005, along with additional fortified food.
Prolonged drought in eastern and southern Ethiopia has led to food insecurity.

2 million people will still need emergency assistance.
To address this food insecurity, a total of 387,500 tonnes of food aid is needed in 2005 for survival programs targeting children under five and pregnant women.
Additionally, 89, 000 tonnes of blended foods and oil are required.
This assistance will be bought locally to help the country's 7 million people.
Farmers play a vital role in the local economy, accounting for about 45% of gross domestic product in Ethiopia.

qwen2.5:1.5b: Ethiopia's crop production increased by 24% compared to 2003 and surpassed historical averages, boosted by better rains, fertilizer use, and seed quality improvements but still leaving 2.2 million people in need of emergency aid.
The report projects additional food needs including 89,000 tonnes for fortified supplementary food programs.
Despite severe drought affecting much of the country's east and south, a local purchase system is recommended by FAO for cereal assistance.
qwen2.5:3b: Ethiopia's crop production increased by 24% to 14.27 million tonnes in 2004, up from 11.49 million tonnes in 2003 and 21% above the previous five-year average.
Contributing factors include good rains, increased fertilizer use, and better seeds.
Despite this rise, nearly 2.2 million Ethiopians still require emergency assistance, with a total need of 387,500 tonnes for 2005.
Additionally, 89,000 tonnes are needed for targeted supplementary food distributions.
In drought-affected eastern and southern regions, 965,000 tonnes were required last year to assist seven million people.
The FAO recommends buying locally to support domestic markets and farmers.
Agriculture is a key sector in Ethiopia, accounting for 45% of GDP with about 80% of the population depending on it.

This report further suggests that crop production has risen 21% more than the average of the last five years.
However, it also highlights that two-thirds (2.2 million) of Ethiopians still require emergency assistance due to lack of support for various food and agriculture-related activities.

On top of that, 89,000 tonnes of fortified blended food and vegetable oil for "targeted supplementary food distributions for a survival programme for children under five and pregnant and lactating women" will be needed.

Despite this remarkable increase, the country still requires emergency food assistance for 2005 due to a prolonged drought affecting eastern and southern Ethiopia, which killed crops and drained wells.
The FAO recommends that local purchasing of cereals is recommended in food assistance programmes to help domestic markets and farmers.
Overall, Ethiopia produced 14.27 million tonnes of crops in 2004, representing a 21% increase compared to the previous year.

Despite these positive developments, an estimated 2.2 million people will still require emergency assistance, highlighting the ongoing struggle in some regions of the country.
The Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) recommend that food assistance is to be bought locally, thus supporting local markets and farmers.

The FAO recommends local purchase of cereals for food assistance programmes to assist domestic markets and farmers.

Rethinking God: A Theological Exploration of a Catholic Moral Center
by James M. Houston Jr.
This book is an attempt to explore the theological basis for the Catholic moral center.
Houston examines various writings from Church history and contemporary Christian scholars, providing insights into how Christian theology contributes to the development of moral principles.

Rejoice in My Suffering: Meditations on John 3:16
by Frederick B. Temple
Temple reflects on passages from the Bible, focusing particularly on John 3:16, which says "God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son."
He uses this verse to explore themes such as grace, love, sacrifice, and redemption.

The Social Transformation of American Catholicism
by Michael J. Pattock
This book examines the role of Catholicism in shaping American society and culture.

Pattock analyzes a variety of sources, including sociological research, legal documents, and theological writings to show how Catholic social teaching has influenced American politics, economics, and social policies.

The Essential Catholic Worker: A Treasury of Wisdom and Guidance
edited by Philip S. Clay
This collection brings together some of the most notable Catholic writers on living as a Christian in the world.
From Dorothy Day's essays on poverty to Howard Schultz's reflections on community service, this book offers guidance and inspiration for living faithfully as Catholics.

Theology That Makes a Difference: 40 Questions for Evangelism
by Robert J. Markel
This book is intended for evangelists and those who want to learn more about evangelizing.
Markel addresses the challenges of sharing one's faith, providing practical advice on how to approach conversations with others.

Theology of Grace: A Study of God's Love in Jesus Christ
by John D. Cross
Cross examines the theological concepts of grace and love through the lens of Christian scripture.
He shows how these concepts are essential for understanding the nature of God, the meaning of human life, and the implications for believers.

Unfinished Business: Women and Catholic Leadership (Hardcover)
by Mary W. Jones
Jones explores issues facing women in the Church and calls for greater recognition and leadership opportunities for women in all areas of Catholic life.
She provides insights on how to overcome obstacles that impede women's full participation in the Church.

The Wisdom of Our Mothers: 365 Meditations for Building Faithful Relationships
by Kristin K. Season
This book is designed as a daily devotional, reflecting on Scripture passages and their applications to real-life situations.
It offers practical advice and insights into how to strengthen relationships with family, friends, and colleagues.

A Catholic Guide to Marriage: Love, Respect, Communication, & Other Topics
by John M. Farley
Farley provides a comprehensive guide to the sacrament of marriage in the Church.

He explores topics such..
- Love: Love is an essential part of marriage, and this book examines how love can be developed.
- Respect: This section explains the importance of showing respect for one's spouse as a sign of God's love.
- Communication: The role of effective communication in building strong relationships with spouses.
- Building Trust: Strategies to build trust between partners.
- Common Challenges: The most common issues faced by married couples, including communication problems and disagreements over finances.

A Catholic Response to Global Warming
by Cardinal Kurt Koch
Koch is a prominent German cardinal who addresses climate change in this book.
He discusses the moral implications of global warming and offers guidance on how Catholics can address environmental concerns while maintaining their faith.

The Book of James: A Commentary
by John J. Henley Jr.
This commentary on the New Testament book of James explores its historical context, cultural background, and theological implications.
It provides an in-depth analysis of key themes such as wisdom, faith, charity, and perseverance.

The Catholic Idea of Salvation: Past, Present, and Future
by Richard J. Dutkiewicz
Dutkiewicz provides a comprehensive overview of the Catholic understanding of salvation, focusing on various aspects of Christian theology.
He explores topics such as redemption, sanctification, justification, and cooperation with God's grace.

The Catholic Seasons: A Journey Through the Year
by Michael H. Cope
This book uses the natural seasons to explore topics related to faith, family, and community.
It addresses various aspects of the year, including the Advent season, Lent, Easter, Christmas, and Holy Week.

The Fivefold Ministry: Priesthood, Prophetery, Ministeriality, Discernment, and Worship
by Fr.

Thomas J. Kelly
This book explores the significance of the fivefold ministry in the Catholic Church.
It examines the roles of priests, prophets, ministers, discerners, and worshippers as essential to promoting holiness and evangelizing.

32 Sins of the Mind: A Study of Christianity and the Human Condition
by James M. Houston Jr.
This comprehensive book offers a critical analysis of Christian thought, exploring the role of conscience in shaping moral principles.
It examines various aspects of human nature, including sin, redemption, and spiritual growth.

33 The Catholic Church and American Politics (2nd Edition)
by Michael J. Haynes
Haynes explores the relationship between the Catholic Church and American politics, analyzing the history of political issues faced by the Church while addressing contemporary challenges such
granite3.1-dense:2b: Ethiopia's 2004 crop production was 14.27 million tonnes, marking a 24% increase from 2003 (11.49 million tonnes) and a 21% rise compared to the average of the previous five years.
Factors contributing to this growth include favorable weather conditions, enhanced use of fertilizers, and improved seeds.
Despite these advancements, 2.2 million Ethiopians still require emergency food assistance in 2005, with estimated requirements at 387,500 tonnes.
Additionally, 89,000 tonnes of fortified blended food and vegetable oil are needed for targeted supplementary nutrition programs for children under five and pregnant/lactating women.
In eastern and southern Ethiopia, a severe drought caused extensive crop loss and dried up wells, necessitating 965,000 tonnes of food assistance in 2003 for seven million people.
The Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) advocates for purchasing local cereals to support both domestic markets and farmers.
Agriculture is Ethiopia's primary economic sector, accounting for 45% of gross domestic product, with approximately 80% of its population relying directly or indirectly on it.

Drought in eastern and southern Ethiopia has worsened food insecurity.
